text.div:
Generated Narrative: StructureDefinition NgPatient

NameFlagsCard.TypeDescription & Constraints
Patient 0..*PatientInformation about an individual or animal receiving health care services
meta
lastUpdated S1..1instantThe date and time when the client record was created or last updated.
implicitRules 0..0
modifierExtension 0..0
identifier S1..*IdentifierAn identifier for this patient
use 0..0
system S1..1uriThe organization website that assign the ID being entered (eg. https://nimc.gov.ng)
value S1..1stringThe actual ID value (eg. NIN35635556)
active 0..1booleanIndicates Whether this patient's record is in active use or not (eg. for Immunization, this flag can be set to true between 0-24 months, and false there after, to optimize searches)
name S1..*HumanNameA name associated with the patient
use 0..0
family 1..1stringThe surname or family name of the client
given 1..*stringThe other names of the client
gender 0..1codeThe sex of the client
Binding: NG-Imm Gender or Sex VS (required)
birthDate S0..1dateThe date of birth of the client in the form dd-mm-yyy
Slices for deceased[x] 0..1boolean, dateTimeIndicates if an individual client is alive or dead
Slice: Unordered, Open by type:$this
deceased[x]:deceasedBoolean 0..1booleanIndicates if the individual is deceased (dead) or not
deceased[x]:deceasedDateTime 0..1dateTimeIndicates when the individual passed away if dead.
address S0..*AddressAn address for the individual
use 0..0
line 0..1stringThe house number number, stree, and name where the Client lives
city 0..1stringThe city, village, town or settlement where the client lives in the state
district 0..1stringThe FHIR name is district, used as Nigeria LGA in this profile
Binding: NG-Imm LGAs VS (required)
state 0..1stringThe name of the state where the client resides in Nigeria
Binding: NG-Imm States VS (required)
photo S0..*AttachmentImage of the patient
contentType 0..1codeType of image (e.g., image/jpeg)
data 0..1base64BinaryBase64 encoded image data
url 0..1urlPublic URL or internal endpoint to the patient's photo
size 0..1unsignedIntThe size of the image in mega bytes MB
title 0..1stringThe label of the image
contact S0..*BackboneElementA contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient
modifierExtension 0..0
name
use 0..0
family 0..1stringThe surname (family) name of the Client's primary Caregiver, can be a Parent or Guardian
given 0..*stringThe first name of the Client's primary Caregiver, can be a Parent or Guardian
telecom S0..*ContactPointA contact detail for the person
system 0..1codeThe primary means to contact the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian
value 0..1stringThe primary means to value(phone no. or email address) the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian
use 0..0
address
use 0..0
line S0..1stringThe line address of the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian
city 0..1stringThe city, town or settlement where the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian lives
district 0..1stringThe LGA where the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian lives
Binding: NG-Imm LGAs VS (required)
state 0..1stringThe State in Nigeria where the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian lives
Binding: NG-Imm States VS (required)
communication
language 1..1CodeableConceptPreferred language which can be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
Binding: NG-Imm Languages VS (extensible)
link
modifierExtension 0..0

Documentation for this format

element.short: Information about an individual or animal receiving health care services
element.definition: Demographics and other administrative information about an individual or animal receiving care or other health-related services.

constraint.human: If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT contain nested Resources
If the resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL be referred to from elsewhere in the resource or SHALL refer to the containing resource
constraint.expression: contained.where((('#'+id in (%resource.descendants().reference | %resource.descendants().as(canonical) | %resource.descendants().as(uri) | %resource.descendants().as(url))) or descendants().where(reference = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists() or descendants().where(as(canonical) = '#').exists()).not()).trace('unmatched', id).empty()
constraint.xpath: not(exists(for $id in f:contained/*/f:id/@value return $contained[not(parent::*/descendant::f:reference/@value=concat('#', $contained/*/id/@value) or descendant::f:reference[@value='#'])]))

constraint.human: If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a meta.versionId or a meta.lastUpdated
If a resource is contained in another resource, it SHALL NOT have a security label

extension.valueMarkdown: When a resource has no narrative, only systems that fully understand the data can display the resource to a human safely. Including a human readable representation in the resource makes for a much more robust eco-system and cheaper handling of resources by intermediary systems. Some ecosystems restrict distribution of resources to only those systems that do fully understand the resources, and as a consequence implementers may believe that the narrative is superfluous. However experience shows that such eco-systems often open up to new participants over time.

constraint.human: A resource should have narrative for robust management

element.short: Logical id of this artifact
element.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
element.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

element.short: Metadata about the resource
element.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Version specific identifier
element.definition: The version specific identifier, as it appears in the version portion of the URL. This value changes when the resource is created, updated, or deleted.
element.comment: The server assigns this value, and ignores what the client specifies, except in the case that the server is imposing version integrity on updates/deletes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The date and time when the client record was created or last updated.
element.definition: When the resource last changed - e.g. when the version changed.
element.comment: This value is always populated except when the resource is first being created. The server / resource manager sets this value; what a client provides is irrelevant. This is equivalent to the HTTP Last-Modified and SHOULD have the same value on a [read](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/http.html#read) interaction.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Identifies where the resource comes from
element.definition: A uri that identifies the source system of the resource. This provides a minimal amount of [Provenance](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/provenance.html#) information that can be used to track or differentiate the source of information in the resource. The source may identify another FHIR server, document, message, database, etc.
element.comment:
In the provenance resource, this corresponds to Provenance.entity.what[x]. The exact use of the source (and the implied Provenance.entity.role) is left to implementer discretion. Only one nominated source is allowed; for additional provenance details, a full Provenance resource should be used. 

This element can be used to indicate where the current master source of a resource that has a canonical URL if the resource is no longer hosted at the canonical URL.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Profiles this resource claims to conform to
element.definition: A list of profiles (references to [StructureDefinition](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/structuredefinition.html#) resources) that this resource claims to conform to. The URL is a reference to [StructureDefinition.url](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/structuredefinition-definitions.html#StructureDefinition.url).
element.comment: It is up to the server and/or other infrastructure of policy to determine whether/how these claims are verified and/or updated over time.  The list of profile URLs is a set.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Security Labels applied to this resource
element.definition: Security labels applied to this resource. These tags connect specific resources to the overall security policy and infrastructure.
element.comment: The security labels can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource. The list of security labels is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Security Labels from the Healthcare Privacy and Security Classification System.

element.short: Tags applied to this resource
element.definition: Tags applied to this resource. Tags are intended to be used to identify and relate resources to process and workflow, and applications are not required to consider the tags when interpreting the meaning of a resource.
element.comment: The tags can be updated without changing the stated version of the resource. The list of tags is a set. Uniqueness is based the system/code, and version and display are ignored.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: Codes that represent various types of tags, commonly workflow-related; e.g. "Needs review by Dr. Jones".

element.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
element.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
element.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because the implicit rules may provide additional knowledge about the resource that modifies it's meaning or interpretation

element.short: Language of the resource content
element.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
element.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
element.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
element.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Contained, inline Resources
element.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
element.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extension
element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the resource that contains them

element.short: An identifier for this patient
element.definition: An identifier for this patient.
element.requirements: Patients are almost always assigned specific numerical identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: usual | official | temp | secondary | old (If known)
element.definition: The purpose of this identifier.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an identifier is permanent unless it explicitly says that it is temporary.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate identifier for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary id for a permanent one.

binding.description: Identifies the purpose for this identifier, if known .

element.short: Description of identifier
element.definition: A coded type for the identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.
element.comment: This element deals only with general categories of identifiers.  It SHOULD not be used for codes that correspond 1..1 with the Identifier.system. Some identifiers may fall into multiple categories due to common usage.   Where the system is known, a type is unnecessary because the type is always part of the system definition. However systems often need to handle identifiers where the system is not known. There is not a 1:1 relationship between type and system, since many different systems have the same type.
element.requirements: Allows users to make use of identifiers when the identifier system is not known.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: A coded type for an identifier that can be used to determine which identifier to use for a specific purpose.

element.short: The organization website that assign the ID being entered (eg. https://nimc.gov.ng)
element.definition: Establishes the namespace for the value - that is, a URL that describes a set values that are unique.
element.comment: Identifier.system is always case sensitive.
element.requirements: There are many sets  of identifiers.  To perform matching of two identifiers, we need to know what set we're dealing with. The system identifies a particular set of unique identifiers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The actual ID value (eg. NIN35635556)
element.definition: The portion of the identifier typically relevant to the user and which is unique within the context of the system.
element.comment: If the value is a full URI, then the system SHALL be urn:ietf:rfc:3986.  The value's primary purpose is computational mapping.  As a result, it may be normalized for comparison purposes (e.g. removing non-significant whitespace, dashes, etc.)  A value formatted for human display can be conveyed using the [Rendered Value extension](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extension-rendered-value.html). Identifier.value is to be treated as case sensitive unless knowledge of the Identifier.system allows the processer to be confident that non-case-sensitive processing is safe.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.extension or II.root if system indicates OID or GUID (Or Role.id.extension or root)

element.short: Time period when id is/was valid for use
element.definition: Time period during which identifier is/was valid for use.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Organization that issued id (may be just text)
element.definition: Organization that issued/manages the identifier.
element.comment: The Identifier.assigner may omit the .reference element and only contain a .display element reflecting the name or other textual information about the assigning organization.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: II.assigningAuthorityName but note that this is an improper use by the definition of the field.  Also Role.scoper

element.short: Indicates Whether this patient's record is in active use or not (eg. for Immunization, this flag can be set to true between 0-24 months, and false there after, to optimize searches)
element.definition:
Whether this patient record is in active use. 
Many systems use this property to mark as non-current patients, such as those that have not been seen for a period of time based on an organization's business rules.

It is often used to filter patient lists to exclude inactive patients

Deceased patients may also be marked as inactive for the same reasons, but may be active for some time after death.
element.comment: If a record is inactive, and linked to an active record, then future patient/record updates should occur on the other patient.
element.requirements: Need to be able to mark a patient record as not to be used because it was created in error.
element.meaningWhenMissing: This resource is generally assumed to be active if no value is provided for the active element

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labelled as a modifier because it is a status element that can indicate that a record should not be treated as valid

element.short: A name associated with the patient
element.definition: A name associated with the individual.
element.comment: A patient may have multiple names with different uses or applicable periods. For animals, the name is a "HumanName" in the sense that is assigned and used by humans and has the same patterns.
element.requirements: Need to be able to track the patient by multiple names. Examples are your official name and a partner name.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc.for a current/permanent one

binding.description: The use of a human name.

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: Specifies the entire name as it should be displayed e.g. on an application UI. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating a name SHALL ensure that when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The surname or family name of the client
element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comment: Family Name may be decomposed into specific parts using extensions (de, nl, es related cultures).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The other names of the client
element.definition: Given name.
element.comment: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name parts. Initials may be separated into multiple given names but often aren't due to paractical limitations.  This element is not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.
element.orderMeaning: Given Names appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Parts that come before the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.
element.orderMeaning: Prefixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Parts that come after the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.
element.orderMeaning: Suffixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A contact detail for the individual
element.definition: A contact detail (e.g. a telephone number or an email address) by which the individual may be contacted.
element.comment: A Patient may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods.  May need to have options for contacting the person urgently and also to help with identification. The address might not go directly to the individual, but may reach another party that is able to proxy for the patient (i.e. home phone, or pet owner's phone).
element.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The sex of the client
element.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the patient is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
element.comment: The gender might not match the biological sex as determined by genetics or the individual's preferred identification. Note that for both humans and particularly animals, there are other legitimate possibilities than male and female, though the vast majority of systems and contexts only support male and female.  Systems providing decision support or enforcing business rules should ideally do this on the basis of Observations dealing with the specific sex or gender aspect of interest (anatomical, chromosomal, social, etc.)  However, because these observations are infrequently recorded, defaulting to the administrative gender is common practice.  Where such defaulting occurs, rule enforcement should allow for the variation between administrative and biological, chromosomal and other gender aspects.  For example, an alert about a hysterectomy on a male should be handled as a warning or overridable error, not a "hard" error.  See the Patient Gender and Sex section for additional information about communicating patient gender and sex.
element.requirements: Needed for identification of the individual, in combination with (at least) name and birth date.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The date of birth of the client in the form dd-mm-yyy
element.definition: The date of birth for the individual.
element.comment: At least an estimated year should be provided as a guess if the real DOB is unknown  There is a standard extension "patient-birthTime" available that should be used where Time is required (such as in maternity/infant care systems).
element.requirements: Age of the individual drives many clinical processes.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Indicates if an individual client is alive or dead
element.definition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not.
element.comment: If there's no value in the instance, it means there is no statement on whether or not the individual is deceased. Most systems will interpret the absence of a value as a sign of the person being alive.
element.requirements: The fact that a patient is deceased influences the clinical process. Also, in human communication and relation management it is necessary to know whether the person is alive.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because once a patient is marked as deceased, the actions that are appropriate to perform on the patient may be significantly different.

mapping.map: player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedInd, player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedTime

element.short: Indicates if the individual is deceased (dead) or not
element.definition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not.
element.comment: If there's no value in the instance, it means there is no statement on whether or not the individual is deceased. Most systems will interpret the absence of a value as a sign of the person being alive.
element.requirements: The fact that a patient is deceased influences the clinical process. Also, in human communication and relation management it is necessary to know whether the person is alive.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because once a patient is marked as deceased, the actions that are appropriate to perform on the patient may be significantly different.

mapping.map: player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedInd, player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedTime

element.short: Indicates when the individual passed away if dead.
element.definition: Indicates if the individual is deceased or not.
element.comment: If there's no value in the instance, it means there is no statement on whether or not the individual is deceased. Most systems will interpret the absence of a value as a sign of the person being alive.
element.requirements: The fact that a patient is deceased influences the clinical process. Also, in human communication and relation management it is necessary to know whether the person is alive.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because once a patient is marked as deceased, the actions that are appropriate to perform on the patient may be significantly different.

mapping.map: player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedInd, player[classCode=PSN|ANM and determinerCode=INSTANCE]/deceasedTime

element.short: An address for the individual
element.definition: An address for the individual.
element.comment: Patient may have multiple addresses with different uses or applicable periods.
element.requirements: May need to keep track of patient addresses for contacting, billing or reporting requirements and also to help with identification.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: home | work | temp | old | billing - purpose of this address
element.definition: The purpose of this address.
element.comment: Applications can assume that an address is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows an appropriate address to be chosen from a list of many.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old address etc.for a current/permanent one

element.short: postal | physical | both
element.definition: Distinguishes between physical addresses (those you can visit) and mailing addresses (e.g. PO Boxes and care-of addresses). Most addresses are both.
element.comment: The definition of Address states that "address is intended to describe postal addresses, not physical locations". However, many applications track whether an address has a dual purpose of being a location that can be visited as well as being a valid delivery destination, and Postal addresses are often used as proxies for physical locations (also see the [Location](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/location.html#) resource).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of an address (physical / postal).

element.short: Text representation of the address
element.definition: Specifies the entire address as it should be displayed e.g. on a postal label. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating an address SHALL ensure that  when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 + XAD.3 + XAD.4 + XAD.5 + XAD.6

element.short: The house number number, stree, and name where the Client lives
element.definition: This component contains the house number, apartment number, street name, street direction,  P.O. Box number, delivery hints, and similar address information.
element.orderMeaning: The order in which lines should appear in an address label

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: XAD.1 + XAD.2 (note: XAD.1 and XAD.2 have different meanings for a company address than for a person address)

element.short: The city, village, town or settlement where the client lives in the state
element.definition: The name of the city, town, suburb, village or other community or delivery center.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The FHIR name is district, used as Nigeria LGA in this profile
element.definition: Full detailed definition for the address district field as Local Government Area
element.comment: District is sometimes known as county, but in some regions 'county' is used in place of city (municipality), so county name should be conveyed in city instead.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The name of the state where the client resides in Nigeria
element.definition: Sub-unit of a country with limited sovereignty in a federally organized country. A code may be used if codes are in common use (e.g. US 2 letter state codes).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Postal code for area
element.definition: A postal code designating a region defined by the postal service.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Country (e.g. can be ISO 3166 2 or 3 letter code)
element.definition: Country - a nation as commonly understood or generally accepted.
element.comment: ISO 3166 3 letter codes can be used in place of a human readable country name.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when address was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when address was/is in use.
element.requirements: Allows addresses to be placed in historical context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Marital (civil) status of a patient
element.definition: This field contains a patient's most recent marital (civil) status.
element.requirements: Most, if not all systems capture it.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The domestic partnership status of a person.

element.short: Whether patient is part of a multiple birth
element.definition: Indicates whether the patient is part of a multiple (boolean) or indicates the actual birth order (integer).
element.comment: Where the valueInteger is provided, the number is the birth number in the sequence. E.g. The middle birth in triplets would be valueInteger=2 and the third born would have valueInteger=3 If a boolean value was provided for this triplets example, then all 3 patient records would have valueBoolean=true (the ordering is not indicated).
element.requirements: For disambiguation of multiple-birth children, especially relevant where the care provider doesn't meet the patient, such as labs.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Image of the patient
element.definition: Image of the patient.
element.comment:
Guidelines:
* Use id photos, not clinical photos.
* Limit dimensions to thumbnail.
* Keep byte count low to ease resource updates.
element.requirements: Many EHR systems have the capability to capture an image of the patient. Fits with newer social media usage too.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

slicing.description: Extensions are always sliced by (at least) url

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Type of image (e.g., image/jpeg)
element.definition: Identifies the type of the data in the attachment and allows a method to be chosen to interpret or render the data. Includes mime type parameters such as charset where appropriate.
element.requirements: Processors of the data need to be able to know how to interpret the data.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The mime type of an attachment. Any valid mime type is allowed.

mapping.map: ED.2+ED.3/RP.2+RP.3. Note conversion may be needed if old style values are being used

element.short: Human language of the content (BCP-47)
element.definition: The human language of the content. The value can be any valid value according to BCP 47.
element.requirements: Users need to be able to choose between the languages in a set of attachments.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Base64 encoded image data
element.definition: The actual data of the attachment - a sequence of bytes, base64 encoded.
element.comment: The base64-encoded data SHALL be expressed in the same character set as the base resource XML or JSON.
element.requirements: The data needs to able to be transmitted inline.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Public URL or internal endpoint to the patient's photo
element.definition: A location where the data can be accessed.
element.comment: If both data and url are provided, the url SHALL point to the same content as the data contains. Urls may be relative references or may reference transient locations such as a wrapping envelope using cid: though this has ramifications for using signatures. Relative URLs are interpreted relative to the service url, like a resource reference, rather than relative to the resource itself. If a URL is provided, it SHALL resolve to actual data.
element.requirements: The data needs to be transmitted by reference.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

mapping.map: RP.1+RP.2 - if they refer to a URL (see v2.6)

element.short: The size of the image in mega bytes MB
element.definition: The number of bytes of data that make up this attachment (before base64 encoding, if that is done).
element.comment: The number of bytes is redundant if the data is provided as a base64binary, but is useful if the data is provided as a url reference.
element.requirements: Representing the size allows applications to determine whether they should fetch the content automatically in advance, or refuse to fetch it at all.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Hash of the data (sha-1, base64ed)
element.definition: The calculated hash of the data using SHA-1. Represented using base64.
element.comment: The hash is calculated on the data prior to base64 encoding, if the data is based64 encoded. The hash is not intended to support digital signatures. Where protection against malicious threats a digital signature should be considered, see [Provenance.signature](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/provenance-definitions.html#Provenance.signature) for mechanism to protect a resource with a digital signature.
element.requirements: Included so that applications can verify that the contents of a location have not changed due to technical failures (e.g., storage rot, transport glitch, incorrect version).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The label of the image
element.definition: A label or set of text to display in place of the data.
element.requirements: Applications need a label to display to a human user in place of the actual data if the data cannot be rendered or perceived by the viewer.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Date attachment was first created
element.definition: The date that the attachment was first created.
element.requirements: This is often tracked as an integrity issue for use of the attachment.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient
element.definition: A contact party (e.g. guardian, partner, friend) for the patient.
element.comment: Contact covers all kinds of contact parties: family members, business contacts, guardians, caregivers. Not applicable to register pedigree and family ties beyond use of having contact.
element.requirements: Need to track people you can contact about the patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
SHALL at least contain a contact's details or a reference to an organization

constraint.xpath: exists(f:name) or exists(f:telecom) or exists(f:address) or exists(f:organization)

element.definition: An Extension

Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: The kind of relationship
element.definition: The nature of the relationship between the patient and the contact person.
element.requirements: Used to determine which contact person is the most relevant to approach, depending on circumstances.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The nature of the relationship between a patient and a contact person for that patient.

element.short: A name associated with the contact person
element.definition: A name associated with the contact person.
element.requirements: Contact persons need to be identified by name, but it is uncommon to need details about multiple other names for that contact person.

element.short: usual | official | temp | nickname | anonymous | old | maiden
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for this name.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a name is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Allows the appropriate name for a particular context of use to be selected from among a set of names.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old name etc.for a current/permanent one

binding.description: The use of a human name.

mapping.map: XPN.7, but often indicated by which field contains the name

element.short: Text representation of the full name
element.definition: Specifies the entire name as it should be displayed e.g. on an application UI. This may be provided instead of or as well as the specific parts.
element.comment: Can provide both a text representation and parts. Applications updating a name SHALL ensure that when both text and parts are present,  no content is included in the text that isn't found in a part.
element.requirements: A renderable, unencoded form.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The surname (family) name of the Client's primary Caregiver, can be a Parent or Guardian
element.definition: The part of a name that links to the genealogy. In some cultures (e.g. Eritrea) the family name of a son is the first name of his father.
element.comment: Family Name may be decomposed into specific parts using extensions (de, nl, es related cultures).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The first name of the Client's primary Caregiver, can be a Parent or Guardian
element.definition: Given name.
element.comment: If only initials are recorded, they may be used in place of the full name parts. Initials may be separated into multiple given names but often aren't due to paractical limitations.  This element is not called "first name" since given names do not always come first.
element.orderMeaning: Given Names appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Parts that come before the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the start of the name.
element.orderMeaning: Prefixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Parts that come after the name
element.definition: Part of the name that is acquired as a title due to academic, legal, employment or nobility status, etc. and that appears at the end of the name.
element.orderMeaning: Suffixes appear in the correct order for presenting the name

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when name was/is in use
element.definition: Indicates the period of time when this name was valid for the named person.
element.requirements: Allows names to be placed in historical context.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A contact detail for the person
element.definition: A contact detail for the person, e.g. a telephone number or an email address.
element.comment: Contact may have multiple ways to be contacted with different uses or applicable periods.  May need to have options for contacting the person urgently, and also to help with identification.
element.requirements: People have (primary) ways to contact them in some way such as phone, email.

element.definition: Telecommunications form for contact point - what communications system is required to make use of the contact.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The primary means to value(phone no. or email address) the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian
element.definition: The actual contact point details, in a form that is meaningful to the designated communication system (i.e. phone number or email address).
element.comment: Additional text data such as phone extension numbers, or notes about use of the contact are sometimes included in the value.
element.requirements: Need to support legacy numbers that are not in a tightly controlled format.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: home | work | temp | old | mobile - purpose of this contact point
element.definition: Identifies the purpose for the contact point.
element.comment: Applications can assume that a contact is current unless it explicitly says that it is temporary or old.
element.requirements: Need to track the way a person uses this contact, so a user can choose which is appropriate for their purpose.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This is labeled as "Is Modifier" because applications should not mistake a temporary or old contact etc.for a current/permanent one

mapping.map: XTN.2 - but often indicated by field

element.short: Specify preferred order of use (1 = highest)
element.definition: Specifies a preferred order in which to use a set of contacts. ContactPoints with lower rank values are more preferred than those with higher rank values.
element.comment: Note that rank does not necessarily follow the order in which the contacts are represented in the instance.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Time period when the contact point was/is in use
element.definition: Time period when the contact point was/is in use.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Address for the contact person
element.definition: Address for the contact person.
element.requirements: Need to keep track where the contact person can be contacted per postal mail or visited.

element.comment: The definition of Address states that "address is intended to describe postal addresses, not physical locations". element.short: male | female | other | unknown
element.definition: Administrative Gender - the gender that the contact person is considered to have for administration and record keeping purposes.
element.requirements: Needed to address the person correctly.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The gender of a person used for administrative purposes.

element.short: Organization that is associated with the contact
element.definition: Organization on behalf of which the contact is acting or for which the contact is working.
element.requirements: For guardians or business related contacts, the organization is relevant.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: The period during which this contact person or organization is valid to be contacted relating to this patient
element.definition: The period during which this contact person or organization is valid to be contacted relating to this patient.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: A language which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
element.definition: A language which may be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health.
element.comment: If no language is specified, this *implies* that the default local language is spoken.  If you need to convey proficiency for multiple modes, then you need multiple Patient.Communication associations.   For animals, language is not a relevant field, and should be absent from the instance. If the Patient does not speak the default local language, then the Interpreter Required Standard can be used to explicitly declare that an interpreter is required.
element.requirements: If a patient does not speak the local language, interpreters may be required, so languages spoken and proficiency are important things to keep track of both for patient and other persons of interest.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
element.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.
element.requirements: Modifier extensions allow for extensions that *cannot* be safely ignored to be clearly distinguished from the vast majority of extensions which can be safely ignored.  This promotes interoperability by eliminating the need for implementers to prohibit the presence of extensions. For further information, see the [definition of modifier extensions](http://hl7.org/fhir/R4/extensibility.html#modifierExtension).

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: Preferred language which can be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
element.definition: The ISO-639-1 alpha 2 code in lower case for the language, optionally followed by a hyphen and the ISO-3166-1 alpha 2 code for the region in upper case; e.g. "en" for English, or "en-US" for American English versus "en-EN" for England English.
element.comment: The structure aa-BB with this exact casing is one the most widely used notations for locale. However not all systems actually code this but instead have it as free text. Hence CodeableConcept instead of code as the data type.
element.requirements: Most systems in multilingual countries will want to convey language. Not all systems actually need the regional dialect.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Language preference indicator
element.definition: Indicates whether or not the patient prefers this language (over other languages he masters up a certain level).
element.comment: This language is specifically identified for communicating healthcare information.
element.requirements: People that master multiple languages up to certain level may prefer one or more, i.e. feel more confident in communicating in a particular language making other languages sort of a fall back method.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Patient's nominated primary care provider
element.definition: Patient's nominated care provider.
element.comment:
This may be the primary care provider (in a GP context), or it may be a patient nominated care manager in a community/disability setting, or even organization that will provide people to perform the care provider roles.  It is not to be used to record Care Teams, these should be in a CareTeam resource that may be linked to the CarePlan or EpisodeOfCare resources.
Multiple GPs may be recorded against the patient for various reasons, such as a student that has his home GP listed along with the GP at university during the school semesters, or a "fly-in/fly-out" worker that has the onsite GP also included with his home GP to remain aware of medical issues.

Jurisdictions may decide that they can profile this down to 1 if desired, or 1 per type.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record
element.definition: Organization that is the custodian of the patient record.
element.comment: There is only one managing organization for a specific patient record. Other organizations will have their own Patient record, and may use the Link property to join the records together (or a Person resource which can include confidence ratings for the association).
element.requirements: Need to know who recognizes this patient record, manages and updates it.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual person
element.definition: Link to another patient resource that concerns the same actual patient.
element.comment: There is no assumption that linked patient records have mutual links.
element.requirements:
There are multiple use cases:   

* Duplicate patient records due to the clerical errors associated with the difficulties of identifying humans consistently, and 
* Distribution of patient information across multiple servers.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.isModifierReason: This element is labeled as a modifier because it might not be the main Patient resource, and the referenced patient should be used instead of this Patient record. This is when the link.type value is 'replaced-by'

element.short: Unique id for inter-element referencing
element.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

element.short: Additional content defined by implementations
element.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
element.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.short: Extension
element.definition: An Extension

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children
Must have either extensions or value[x], not both

element.isModifierReason: Modifier extensions are expected to modify the meaning or interpretation of the element that contains them

element.short: The other patient or related person resource that the link refers to
element.definition: The other patient resource that the link refers to.
element.comment: Referencing a RelatedPerson here removes the need to use a Person record to associate a Patient and RelatedPerson as the same individual.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

element.short: replaced-by | replaces | refer | seealso
element.definition: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

constraint.human: All FHIR elements must have a @value or children

binding.description: The type of link between this patient resource and another patient resource.

element.short: The date and time when the client record was created or last updated.
The organization website that assign the ID being entered (eg. https://nimc.gov.ng)
The actual ID value (eg. NIN35635556)
Indicates Whether this patient's record is in active use or not (eg. for Immunization, this flag can be set to true between 0-24 months, and false there after, to optimize searches)
The surname or family name of the client
The other names of the client
The sex of the client
The date of birth of the client in the form dd-mm-yyy
Indicates if an individual client is alive or dead
Indicates if the individual is deceased (dead) or not
Indicates when the individual passed away if dead.
The house number number, stree, and name where the Client lives
The city, village, town or settlement where the client lives in the state
The FHIR name is district, used as Nigeria LGA in this profile
element.definition: Full detailed definition for the address district field as Local Government Area

element.short: The name of the state where the client resides in Nigeria
Type of image (e.g., image/jpeg)
Base64 encoded image data
Public URL or internal endpoint to the patient's photo
The size of the image in mega bytes MB
The label of the image
The surname (family) name of the Client's primary Caregiver, can be a Parent or Guardian
The first name of the Client's primary Caregiver, can be a Parent or Guardian
The primary means to contact the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian
The primary means to value(phone no. or email address) the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian
The line address of the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian
The city, town or settlement where the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian lives
The LGA where the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian lives
The State in Nigeria where the Client's primary Caregiver or Guardian lives
Preferred language which can be used to communicate with the patient about his or her health
